title: Colosseum Opens Its Belly to the Public step 3
abstract: The underground warren where ancient Roman gladiators and animals awaited their fates has been restored.

multimedia.caption: The opening of the Colosseum’s underground corridors marks the end of the second of three phases of a multimillion-euro project.

title: Fight and Flight: T.S.A. to Resume Self-Defense Classes for Airline Crews
abstract: The classes, which will resume in July, come as crew members struggle with a surge in cases of unruly passengers.

multimedia.caption: Self-defense training offered by the Transportation Security Administration is designed to help flight crew members handle tense and violent situations with passengers.

title: Next Year, Brits Will Fly Abroad. For Now, It’s Bognor Bingo.
abstract: With flying discouraged, vacation spots that had been fading and unfashionable are having a moment.

multimedia.caption: The Waterloo Square Bowling Club in Bognor Regis. The town earned the title of worst U.K. seaside resort in a 2019 consumer survey.

title: Southwest Airlines to raise minimum wage to $15 an hour to attract and retain workers.
abstract: Pay scales vary by function and by union agreements, but the raise will boost wages by an average of $1.30 per hour. For some workers at the lower end of their pay scales, that could equate to a boost of 3 to 10 percent, the airline said.

title: Summer Is a Scam. Here’s How to Fix It.
abstract: Plus, typeface puzzles, the “Dragon Man” skull and more in the Friday edition of the Science Times Newsletter.

title: Celebrity Cruises will be the first cruise line to resume sailing from a U.S. port.
abstract: The Celebrity Edge will depart from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., on Saturday with 95 percent of its passengers all crew members vaccinated.

multimedia.caption: The Celebrity Edge, docked at Port Everglades in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., will sail at 35 percent capacity on Saturday.

title: Specialized Experiences Offer Fresh Looks on Paris
abstract: As visitors trickle back into the city after a heavy year, walking tours and other experiences that emphasize seldom-told stories about local life and history are taking on new resonance.

multimedia.caption: Located in the Luxembourg Gardens, the le cri, l’écrit sculpture, by Fabrice Hyber, is meant to commemorate the abolition of slavery and is discussed on walking tours organized by Le Paris Noir.
multimedia.copyright: Joann Pai for The New York Times

title: The T List: Five Things We Recommend This Week
abstract: Two new loafers from Martiniano Lopez Crozet, portraits of botanicals — and more.

title: Southwest Names the Airline’s Next Chief Executive
abstract: Robert Jordan, a 33-year veteran at Southwest, will take over for Gary Kelly, the longtime chief, early next year.

title: House Hunting in the Bahamas: A Remote Beachfront Bungalow
abstract: The region’s housing market is recovering not just from the pandemic, but from Hurricane Dorian in 2019. And that recovery is in full swing.

multimedia.caption: The property, with 150 feet of white-sand beachfront, sits in the resort community of Kamalame Cay. The villa’s owner has the option of buying a membership at the resort and using its amenities.

title: Airlines struggle to cope as travel picks up and storms force delays.
abstract: Nearly 10,000 flights were delayed on Sunday, the busiest day for U.S. airports since the pandemic arrived.

title: Airline ticket sales dipped in May, but the industry remains optimistic.
abstract: Americans spent 4 percent less on flights in May than in April, and 20 percent less than May 2019.

title: Canadian Couple Who Flew to Indigenous Town for Vaccine Plead Guilty
abstract: The couple, a gambling executive and an actress, were fined $2,300 for violating coronavirus restrictions but won’t face jail time, court records show.

title: Want a Completely Private Destination Wedding? Rent a Resort.
abstract: With more couples looking to create a safer travel experience for their guests, hotels and resorts that offer buyout wedding options are seeing an increase in requests.

title: House Hunting in Italy: Sitting Seaside on Sardinia for $760,000
abstract: The pandemic has driven up prices in the coastal areas of northern Sardinia, where home buyers are now competing with investors.

title: Who Wants a Hotel With a Hallway Anyway?
abstract: “Motor lodges.” “High-end motels.” “Exterior-corridor hotels.” Whatever you call them, the “motorist’s hotel” has gotten a boost these past 15 months. Now about that reputation …

multimedia.caption: “It’s not the motel experience,” said Kristin Huxta Bradley, senior director of communications for Kimpton, about the Goodland, a converted 1960s property outside Santa Barbara. “It’s a boutique hotel.”

title: A Birding Adventure in Arizona’s ‘Sky Islands’
abstract: Separated by seas of desert, mountainous enclaves attract birds from miles around, among them: broad-billed hummingbirds, olive warblers and the elusive elegant trogon, relentlessly pursued by the author.

multimedia.caption: Left: A broad-billed hummingbird on the grounds of the the Santa Rita Lodge in Arizona’s Madera Canyon. Right: A view of the desert on a drive to Portal, Ariz.
